Award.AwardTitle: Air pollution, environmental justice and urban form

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: 1236800 (Marshall). Outdoor air pollution is among the top 10 causes of mortality in the U.S. (and is the largest environmental cause), annually responsible for ~1% of total deaths. Those health risks are not evenly distributed among the population. An important aspect of sustainable development is to understand how urban design and urban environments can help meet social and ?fairness? goals, including avoiding large imbalances in environmental risks among subpopulations?especially along lines of race or income. This project will uncover new relationships among air pollution, demographic attributes relevant to environmental justice, and the spatial layout of urban areas; and will develop an education and outreach program to engage disadvantaged youths. Objectives are to (1) characterize spatial patterns in air pollution concentrations throughout the U.S., and over time, (2) characterize spatial relationships between air pollution and demographic attributes relevant to environmental justice (EJ), covering multiple spatial scales (national, state, county, and urban); (3) identify how shifts in the spatial layout of cities relate to air pollution metrics relevant for EJ; and (4) integrate research findings into education and outreach. The research approach uses an air pollution model that incorporates available demographic data (US Census) and pollution measurements by the U.S. EPA, satellite-based measures of air pollution, and information about land uses (e.g., roads, built-up areas, parks). The model offers spatial precision and therefore provides a good basis for predicting how concentrations vary among communities. New knowledge generated will be integrated into education and outreach activities, including a program to engage high school students in disadvantaged communities and challenge them to investigate and address EJ conditions locally. Targeted results will generate new knowledge relevant to EJ conditions, how they are changing, and how they relate to urban form. Research and outreach activities will identify and test potential solutions. The project will provide observational evidence relating air pollution and demographic attributes such as race and income; and, will explore how those relationships (i) vary with spatial scale of analysis (from within-urban to national-scale) and over time, and (ii) correlate with the spatial layout of urban areas. The combination of available data, including new satellite measurements, with cutting-edge, high-resolution pollution models will provide a novel approach for understanding these issues. It is anticipated that findings will advance theory and practice in environmental sustainability by exploring a long-term factor influencing air pollution (urban form) and by uncovering equity aspects of environmental impacts. The high-precision air pollution models to be developed have the potential to be useful to researchers in outside fields such as environmental epidemiology and environmental economics. Findings will be integrated into existing curricula and programs aimed at increasing science and engineering enrollment of underrepresented students. A new program will challenge students to explore community-scale solutions. Research findings, quantifying conditions relevant to EJ for cities and regions throughout U.S., will be shared directly with local, state, and national environmental policy makers. An interactive website will allow the public to explore spatially precise estimates of long-term air pollution in their neighborhood.

POR.DRECONTENT:
According to the Global Burden of Disease, ambient air pollution is the leading environmental risk factor, and 5th overall risk factor for global deaths, annually responsible for ~8% (4.5 million) of total deaths. Those health risks are not evenly distributed among the population. In the United States, environmental injustice in air pollution exposure is well documented: we identified more than 140 studies that reported higher air pollution exposures for lower-income and/or race-ethnicity minority groups. An important aspect of sustainable development is to understand the patterns of environmental injustice and how those patterns have changed over time. Additionally, it is important to understand how urban design and emission reductions strategies can improve total exposure while meeting social and “fairness” goals, including avoiding large imbalances in environmental risks among subpopulations—especially along lines of race or income. Our research employs measurements and model predictions of outdoor air pollution to improve our understanding of the relationships between air pollution, demographic attributes relevant to environmental justice, and the spatial layout of urban areas. Key research activities and findings are

 

(1) Employing satellite-based measurements of urban form and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), an important traffic pollutant, to explore the effect of urban form on air pollution for a global data set of 1,303 cities. Three of the urban form metrics studied (contiguity, circularity, and vegetation) have a small but significant effect on urban NO2; their combined effect could be substantial. For example, on average, a city at the 75th percentile for all three urban-form metrics could accommodate twice the population as a city at the 25th percentile, while maintaining the same air quality. That finding highlights the potential for urban form as a strategy to address air pollution.

 

(2) Development of one of the first satellite-based national-scale spatiotemporal land use regression models for NO2 in the United States, enabling longitudinal studies of within-city variability (~100 m spatial resolution) in outdoor NO2 concentrations and exposures. To facilitate use of our results, we estimated monthly NO2 concentrations at the centroid locations for all ~8 million Census blocks in the contiguous United States. (“Block” is the Census’s smallest spatial unit.) and made this data publicly and freely available online. Through this work, we also demonstrated an approach to extend temporal coverage to existing models of long-term air pollution concentration.

 

(3) Employing the spatiotemporal NO2 concentration estimates from the land use regression model and Census demographic data, we estimate residential exposures by race-ethnicity, socioeconomic characteristics, and by location (region, state, county, urban area) for the contiguous US in years 2000 and 2010. Reductions in NO2 exposure disparities by race-ethnicity were substantial on an absolute basis: mean change in nonwhite/white exposure difference was -2.1 ppb (5.0 ppb in 2000, 2.9 ppb in 2010). On a relative basis, exposure disparities persisted: relative mean change in nonwhite/white exposure difference was only -2 percentage units (33% in 2000, 31% in 2010). Nonwhites remained ~3 times more likely than whites to live in a Block Group with NO2 concentration above WHO annual guidelines (3.0 times more likely in 2000, 2.5 times more likely in 2010). Conclusions: During 2000-2010, for NO2 concentrations in the contiguous US, environmental injustice decreased substantially on an absolute basis, but less so on a relative basis. Even with those improvements, levels of injustice are high and of concern.

 

 (4) We consider changes in emissions in various locations throughout a case study region and estimate the resulting changes in four metrics: total health impact, the measures’ efficiency at reducing exposures (i.e., impacts per emission reduced), exposure inequality (i.e., deviations from exposures being equal among individuals) and exposure injustice (i.e., correlations between exposure and demographic attributes such as race or income). Results indicate potential trade-offs (e.g., an increase in equality but reduction in justice for certain emissions reductions) as well as opportunities for “win-wins” (e.g. locations for which emission-reductions benefit all four metrics). We identify areas where emission-reductions would result in disproportionately large improvements to average exposures, exposure inequality, and exposure injustice. This approach offers a way to address total exposures and exposure disparities in prioritizing among emission reductions.
